title: How are stage names legal? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: For the same reason that pseudonyms are legal. You can call yourself whatever you like and there is no law against doing so, as long as all your financial records and transactions match up with your real name.

If I ask you your name, are you legally obligated to tell me the truth? Have you ever seen an old hotel register? Guests signed in on a line. It was a formality. At one point, before I ever rented a hotel room, guests didn’t have to provide identification. Now, they require an ID and a credit card, and the two have to match. Banks have the legal right to insist on correct, official names. Other businesses do, too. However, Starbucks doesn’t; I could tell them my name is “Charlemagne”, and see if they could manage the spelling and pronunciation (if I wanted to piss of the Starbucks workers, which I don’t). My advisor in grad school went by her maiden name professionally. Her email, her publications, and her office sign were all in her maiden name. I didn’t even know that she had taken her husband’s last name legally until I happened to see something, I think related to a contract for a conference she was chairing and I was working on.

I have beard that certain unions don’t like confusion. If, for instance, someone shows up with the same real name as an established performer, the newbie is required to take a stage name. Could be speculation, of course. But I did know a Richard Harris in high school who was damned good at musical theater and did at least some professional stuff after graduating. But I lost track after that.

As long as a person isn’t committing fraud, a stage name or even a nickname is legal to use. A friend of mine uses a stage name for his DJ work. He real last name is Leszczak, not a name that is easy to pronounce for most Americans, at least if you’ve not seen it before. Oddly enough for his acting work he uses his real last name, since he is mostly an extra. My sister was in radio and had a very good real name, so she used it, but her friends often used stage names.
